docs.abstract: John James, a candidate for Senate in Michigan, is grappling with heavy and complicated questions as he tries to lead in President Trump’s Republican Party.
docs.snippet: John James, a candidate for Senate in Michigan, is grappling with heavy and complicated questions as he tries to lead in President Trump’s Republican Party.
docs.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — John James still feels the sting from the harrowing encounters and indignities he has experienced as a young Black man crossing paths with the police.

headline.main: A Black Republican Feels the Sting of Racism but Is Silent on Trump
headline.print_headline: A Black Republican Feels the Sting of Racism, but Stays Silent on Trump

byline.original: By Jeremy W. Peters and Kathleen Gray

docs.abstract: As games return and dozens of players drop to one knee, leagues that once tried to tiptoe around the issue won’t be able to avoid it.
docs.snippet: As games return and dozens of players drop to one knee, leagues that once tried to tiptoe around the issue won’t be able to avoid it.
docs.lead_paragraph: A strange thing happened while most professional sports were away, shuttered by the coronavirus.

headline.main: The Anthem Debate Is Back. But Now It’s Standing That’s Polarizing.
headline.print_headline: As Sports Return, It’s Time To Kneel and Be Counted

docs.abstract: As the pandemic continues to derail the global economy, artists share works that reflect on uncertainty, capitalism and racial injustice.
docs.snippet: As the pandemic continues to derail the global economy, artists share works that reflect on uncertainty, capitalism and racial injustice.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 virus has sent the global economy spinning into a state of profound disturbance, casting the livelihoods of individuals and small businesses into doubt and leaving entire industries devastated. The financial impact of the pandemic on local communities, as cities and states slash budgets, and on the world at large will continue to play out in the months and years to come. For the fourth installment of our series T Agitprop, we asked 12 contemporary artists, including Torkwase Dyson, Tomashi Jackson, Isaac Julien and Agnieszka Kurant, to contribute works, most of them new and created exclusively for T, in response to this global emergency. Here are their pieces and statements.

docs.abstract: In an era when viewers are re-evaluating the cop show, the detective series starring Peter Falk still stands out, the writer argues: Columbo was all about sticking it to the man.
docs.snippet: In an era when viewers are re-evaluating the cop show, the detective series starring Peter Falk still stands out, the writer argues: Columbo was all about sticking it to the man.
docs.lead_paragraph: My television goals were moderately ambitious these past few months under quarantine: “I’m finally going to finish ‘The Americans’ and start ‘The West Wing,’” I told myself. “And then I’ll investigate Korean dramas.”

headline.print_headline: Just One More Thing, One More Time

docs.abstract: Makur Maker, a star basketball recruit, chose Howard University over offers from U.C.L.A. and Kentucky, and said he hoped other athletes would consider programs at historically Black institutions.
docs.snippet: Makur Maker, a star basketball recruit, chose Howard University over offers from U.C.L.A. and Kentucky, and said he hoped other athletes would consider programs at historically Black institutions.
docs.lead_paragraph: On June 2, as Black Lives Matter protesters swarmed America’s streets demanding an end to the racist vestiges of America’s troubled past, a teenager from a San Diego suburb posted eight words on Twitter that would soon ignite a less visible, though perhaps just as powerful, movement.

headline.main: Black Lives Matter Protests Spawn Push for Athletes to Attend Historically Black Colleges
headline.print_headline: For Some Athletes, History Becomes New Again

docs.abstract: When mothers take to the streets — particularly those from privileged groups — governments take note. The “wall of moms” in Portland has taken up the cause against police violence.
docs.snippet: When mothers take to the streets — particularly those from privileged groups — governments take note. The “wall of moms” in Portland has taken up the cause against police violence.
docs.lead_paragraph: Wearing matching shades of white or yellow, the women of the “Wall of Moms” in Portland, Ore., have become instant icons of the city’s protests, though the mothers nightly gatherings only began last Saturday and the city’s protests have been going on for more than a month.

headline.main: Mothers’ Power in U.S. Protests Echoes a Global Tradition
headline.print_headline: U.S. Mothers’ Voices, Raised in Protest,  Join Global Tradition

docs.abstract: Instructors and students say that diverse communities can benefit from classes focused on people of color.
docs.snippet: Instructors and students say that diverse communities can benefit from classes focused on people of color.
docs.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Beverly Grant spent years juggling many roles before yoga helped her restore her balance.

headline.main: Black Yoga Collectives Aim to Make Space for Healing
headline.print_headline: Black Yoga Collectives Make Space for Healing

docs.abstract: Many Americans, fearful of the virus, stayed at home and held muted celebrations, although some went on undeterred.
docs.snippet: Many Americans, fearful of the virus, stayed at home and held muted celebrations, although some went on undeterred.
docs.lead_paragraph: Fear hung over the Fourth of July holiday this year as the worsening coronavirus pandemic caused many Americans to pull back from their usual celebrations.

headline.main: Fourth of July Celebrations Dulled by Soaring Coronavirus Cases
headline.print_headline: Virus Fears Overshadow  Many Usual Festivities  On Independence Day

docs.abstract: The president is looking for a dangerous domestic enemy to fight.
docs.snippet: The president is looking for a dangerous domestic enemy to fight.
docs.lead_paragraph: Some presidents, when they get into trouble before an election, try to “wag the dog” by starting a war abroad. Donald Trump seems ready to wag the dog by starting a war at home. Be afraid — he just might get his wish.

docs.abstract: An open letter published by Harper’s, signed by luminaries including Margaret Atwood and Wynton Marsalis, argued for openness to “opposing views.” The debate began immediately.
docs.snippet: An open letter published by Harper’s, signed by luminaries including Margaret Atwood and Wynton Marsalis, argued for openness to “opposing views.” The debate began immediately.
docs.lead_paragraph: The killing of George Floyd has brought an intense moment of racial reckoning in the United States. As protests spread across the country, they have been accompanied by open letters calling for — and promising — change at white-dominated institutions across the arts and academia.

headline.main: Artists and Writers Warn of an ‘Intolerant Climate.’ Reaction Is Swift.
headline.print_headline: In a Letter, Artists and Scholars Warn of an ‘Intolerant Climate’

byline.original: By Jennifer Schuessler and Elizabeth A. Harris
